analyzeResult.content:
NEW YORK, THURSDAY, AUGUST 31, 1967
NONSMOKERS GET CUT ON INSURANCE
Some Companies Are Giving Up to 6% Off on Premiums
. By MURRAY SCHUMACH Lower premium rates are being offered to nonsmokers; by some Insurance companies as the significance of health reports on cigarette hazards has begun to be reflected in policies.
.
Varying with the company and type of life insurance pol- ley, the nonsmoker can now save as much as 6 per cent of the premium, according to in -! formation supplied by a num- ber of companies.
: Though the distinction be- tween smokers and nonsmokers Is being made by relatively few companies so far, there are Indications that a trend may be under way.
For among the companies that have decided to favor the nonsmoker - or penalize the smoker - Is Metropolitan Life, one of the giants of the in- dustry.
. Another major company. the Prudential Insurance Company of America, has not incorpor- ated this idea in any policies. but it is concerned about the correlation of death and smok- Ing.
.. Dr. Andrew J. Oberlander, medical director of the East-
Continued on Page 30, Column 4
NONSMOKERS GET .CUT ON INSURANCE
Continued From Page 1, Col. 1 ern region of Prudential, says: "This matter is certainly a problem, not only for us, but for the whole industry. I think all companies are seriously concerned about it."
The only unconditional allow- ances for the nonsmoker are being offered by a relatively small insurance company, the State Mutual Life Assurance Company of America, of Wor- cester. Mass.
This company offers what surance company defines non- smoker as anyone who has not! smoked a cigarette for at least a year before the policy. Cigar and pipe smokers qualify as nonsmokers.
"We know that some smok- ers may lie," a representative of the company said, "but we feel the number is so small it is not worth bothering about.""
The favoritism shown to non- smokers by Metropolitan Life is more limited. If a policy-hold- er with a cardio-vascular or lung disease is a smoker, the "rate is higher than for persons with the same ailments who do not smoke.
However, no distinction is made between smokers and nonsmokers if they are free of such ailments.
Another variation of benefit for nonsmokers is being offered by the Phoenix Mutual Life In- surance Company, of Hartford.
"In its contracts, the non- smoker must go without a cigarette for at least a year, and must also not be exces- sively overweight.
Among the giant companies that have made no allowance, for nonsmokers and have no Immediate plans to do so are the Equitable Life Assurance Society of the United States and the John Hancock Mutual Life Insurance Company.
Aware of Situation
"We don't give any induce- ments to nonsmokers." spokesman for Equitable said. "but we are certainly aware off the situation. We have a house! organ for executives that has paid a great deal of attention to the stories about smoking."
At John Hancock, the ex- planation was that "smoking is so universal it does not scom practical to make such distinc- tions." Another point stressed at this company was that it was difficult to ascertain if a policyholder smoked or not.
One company that tried and then abandoned a special pol- icy for nonsmokers is the American Family Life Insur-" ance Company, of Columbus, Ga. Â·Georgia.
"We tried it a few years ago: for a few months," according. to W. L. Amos, executive vice, president. "I suppose you might, say we didn't give a very long. trial. But we found that the" nonsmoker policies were being sold to smokers. It was just, more trouble than it wasj worth."
-But Ladd Plumley, chairman of the board and president of State Mutual, said in a recent report to stockholders: "The growing popularity of State Mutual's Non-Cigarette Smoker Life Insurance Pian continued! unabated."
